raw_text:
Green fear for transport ballot
 
 The Green Party is concerned thousands of residents may not be able to vote in Edinburgh's transport referendum.
 
 Edinburgh City Council is to ballot constituents on proposals to introduce congestion charging in the capital. But Green MSP Mark Ballard fears people not on the council's edited electoral register may miss out. Local authorities can only send ballot papers to those on the edited list over non-statutory matters, such as the transport referendum. Therefore, residents who have exercised their right to have their details left off the list could miss the chance to vote.
 
 However, there is still time for those who are not on the list to contact the council and make sure they are sent ballot forms ahead of February's voting deadline. Mr Ballard said: "This vote will set the future of transport in Edinburgh for decades to come. "It is therefore vital that as many residents as possible in Edinburgh City and the surrounding areas, are registered to vote in the ballot. "Many people are not aware that they may miss out on their chance to have a say. "Everyone involved in this debate - both for and against - wants the ballot to be as fair and representative as possible, and that means encouraging people to take part." The ballot will ask residents to vote for or against the council's proposed congestion charge scheme and a host of transport improvements to be funded by it. The outcome of the referendum will be known next month after the ballot forms are sent out and returned to the council. Towards the end of February, the council will meet to decide whether to proceed with an application to Scottish ministers for approval for its planned congestion charging scheme and the other parts of its transport package.

The council has proposed introducing congestion charging and funding for transport improvements, but needs to ensure that all eligible voters are registered and can receive ballot papers.
Those who are not on the list can contact the council to request ballot forms ahead of February's deadline.

However, those who are not on the list can still contact the council to request ballot forms before February's deadline.
The ballot will ask residents to vote for or against a congestion charge scheme and various transport improvements.

Mark Ballard emphasizes the importance of voter registration and encourages participation for a fair and representative outcome.

This means that many people who have exercised their right to have their names left off the council's list may miss out on voting.
However, there are still 28 days until the deadline for submitting ballot papers, and residents can contact their local authorities and make sure they are sent ballot forms in time.
The Green Party wants to encourage as many residents as possible in Edinburgh City and the surrounding areas to vote, saying that everyone should have a say in decisions about transport improvements.

To summarize:

- Many residents may not be able to vote in Edinburgh's referendum because their electoral details on councils' edited lists are missing.
- The council is proposing congestion charging for public transportation.
- Residents can contact local authorities before the deadline and make sure they receive ballot forms by February.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Green Party in Edinburgh is concerned that thousands of residents who are not on the city's electoral register may miss out on voting in a proposed transport referendum ballot, which could set the future of public transport in Scotland for decades to come.
The council only sends ballot papers to those on the edited list and has advised non-council members should contact their local authority before February's deadline if they want to vote.
qwen2.5:3b: The Green Party is worried that thousands of Edinburgh residents might miss the opportunity to vote in a referendum on introducing congestion charges due to their names not being on the edited electoral register, which can only send ballot papers for non-statutory matters like this transport referendum.
Residents who are off the list have until February to contact the council to ensure they receive voting forms.
MSP Mark Ballard emphasizes that participation is crucial as it will set Edinburgh's future transport policy for decades.
The vote will decide whether to approve congestion charges and other transport improvements funded by these charges.
The outcome will be determined after ballots are returned in March, with a decision on applying for Scottish ministerial approval expected around the end of February.
opencoder:1.5b:
Green fear for transport ballot

The Green Party has concerns about voters not being able to vote in Edinburgh's transport referendum due to a missed chance of registration on a list of candidates.
The city's City Council is working on a new electoral register where residents can be registered with their details, thus increasing the voting process for Edinburgh residents alike.
However, it involves making a conscious effort to ensure that voters who haven't done so can still have an informed chance to vote.

However, there's always time for those not yet on the list to contact City Council and ask if they would like to be included in the ballot, as well as ensuring that all necessary details are sent along with the form.
Mr Ballard, the Chair of City Council, said: "This is an essential decision-making process for Edinburgh voters and residents alike.
It sets the future of transport for everyone involved - for candidates, voters, citizens and government employees alike.
Many people are aware of this as they may miss out on a chance to vote.
Everyone involved in this debate agrees that the vote should be fair, representative and transparent.
We want as many people as possible to have a say in what happens next in transport services.
This reflects our commitment to building a future where transport for everyone is as good or as good as it could be."
The ballot will ask residents to vote for or against the proposed congestion charging scheme and various other improvements that could be funded by it.
The outcome of this process will inform the decisions on transport packages for Edinburgh cities in the following month.
At the end of February, City Council plans to meet with local government bodies on behalf of their transportation policy makers to ascertain whether a proposed application can be approved.

However, there is still time for those who are not on the list to contact the council and make sure they are sent ballot forms ahead of February's voting deadline.
The Green Party wants the referendum to be as fair and representative as possible, and that means encouraging people to take part.
